parameters.imbgeco: a numeric vector for if respondent thinks immigrants are generally good or bad for UK's economy. Higher values = good
parameters.endintrvw: a Date for the interview end date
parameters.female: a numeric vector for whether the respondent is a woman
parameters.region: a character vector for the region of the UK the respondent lives
parameters.immigsent:
a numeric vector for immigration sentiment (i.e. imbgeco +
imueclt + imwbcnt). Higher values = more pro-immigration sentiment
parameters.hinctnta: a numeric vector for household income in deciles
parameters.cntry: a character vector for the country (i.e. the UK)
parameters.brncntr: a numeric vector for if the respondent was born in the UK
parameters.stintrvw: a Date for the interview start date
parameters.lrscale: a numeric vector for the ideology of the respondent on an 11-point scale, from 0 to 10
parameters.imueclt: a numeric vector for if respondent thinks immigrants enrich or undermine UK's culture. Higher values = enrich more than undermine
parameters.essround: a numeric for the ESS round
parameters.eduyrs: a numeric vector for total years of education for the respondent
parameters.agea: a numeric vector for the respondent's age in years
parameters.name: a character for the name of the survey
parameters.edition: a character for the particular edition of the ESS round
parameters.uempla: a numeric vector for whether the respondent is currently unemployed but seeking work
parameters.imwbcnt: a numeric vector for if respondent thinks immigrants make UK a better place to live. Higher values = better place to live

description:
Description
This is a replication data originally set to accompany a blog post and
presentation to students at the University of Nottingham in March 2020.
However, COVID-19 led to the cancellation of the talk.
title: British Attitudes Toward Immigration (2018-19)
format: A data frame with 1,905 observations on the following 19 variables.
